newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Feeds trade sees no impact from Antwerp strike.
newsitem.headline: Feeds trade sees no impact from Antwerp strike.

text.p: Dutch meals and feeds traders on Monday played down any market impact from the one-day strike at the port of Antwerp, which has completely blocked traffic.
The port, the second biggest in Europe, has relatively little feedstuffs coming into it -- the region's main entry points being Rotterdam, Amsterdam and Ghent.
"It's not really a main port for the feed market and it's only 24 hours," one trader said, adding that exports of European Union grain may be affected.
The strike was prompted by plans to change workers' status from public sector employees to private sector ones.
A port authority spokesman said the entire port was blocked and although some pilot services were working and a few bridges open, no traffic was possible due to the closure of the locks.
Other feeds traders said the Cargill oilseed crushing plant in Antwerp -- may be affected by the action but because of the short duration of the strike said the impact would be limited.
Noone at Cargill's Amsterdam headquarters was available for comment.
